title: 109_hr2510
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Dietary Supplement Regulatory Implementation Act of 2005". The Congress finds that over 158 million Americans use dietary supplements to improve their health, with consumer spending reaching $20.5 billion in 2004. The FDA predicts continued growth in supplement use due to factors like the aging population and advances in science. The Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 aimed to maintain consumer access to supplements and promote research. DSHEA, enacted in 1994, regulates dietary supplements by requiring truthful, non-misleading claims on labels, setting manufacturing standards, and treating supplements like foods, not drugs. Manufacturers must submit adequate information for regulatory purposes. DSHEA, enacted in 1994, regulates dietary supplements by requiring safety information for new ingredients, giving FDA powers to remove unsafe supplements, establishing the Office of Dietary Supplements for research, and stating the FDA needs more resources to enforce DSHEA effectively. Congress has allocated additional funds for enforcement. The FDA states that full implementation of DSHEA would require between $24,000,000 and $65,000,000 per year. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION AND APPROPRIATION OF RESOURCES. Authorization of Appropriations for the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 and regulatory requirements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act include:
- $30,000,000 for fiscal year 2007
- $40,000,000 for fiscal year 2008
- $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2009
- $65,000,000 for fiscal year 2010
Additionally, $20,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2006. The Office of Dietary Supplements is authorized to receive funding for research and development of consumer information on dietary supplements. $30,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2006, with additional sums authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2010. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will use $30,000,000 to regulate dietary supplements in fiscal year 2006. SEC. 4. ANNUAL ACCOUNTABILITY REPORT ON THE REGULATION OF DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on the implementation and enforcement of the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994. The report includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to dietary supplement regulation and adverse event reporting systems within the Food and Drug Administration. The annual report to Congress includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to enforcement of dietary supplement labeling, good manufacturing practices inspections, and new ingredient reviews by the Food and Drug Administration. It also summarizes the number of inspections and enforcement actions taken. The annual report to Congress includes details on enforcement actions by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services related to dietary supplements, including false claims, research activities supported by the Office of Dietary Supplements, and any recommendations for administrative or legislative actions. The Secretary may provide recommendations for administrative or legislative actions regarding the regulation of dietary supplements, as well as any other relevant information deemed appropriate. SEC. 5. Dietary supplements with ephedrine alkaloids. The Congress acknowledges that dietary supplements containing ephedrine alkaloids may pose a risk of illness or injury. They have granted the Secretary the authority to remove such supplements from the market if deemed necessary. If the Secretary determines that a dietary supplement with ephedrine alkaloids presents a significant risk, all supplements with these alkaloids should be declared adulterated. The Congress acknowledges the risk of dietary supplements containing ephedrine alkaloids and grants the Secretary authority to remove them from the market if necessary. The Secretary should ensure the availability of botanical sources of ephedrine alkaloids in unaltered forms, marketed at traditional dosages, and labeled only for traditional uses. SEC. 6. EDUCATION PROGRAMS REGARDING DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The Secretary will implement education programs for health care professionals and consumers on the safety, health benefits, and potential interactions of dietary supplements. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006 for health professional education. Public education forums, advertisements, and the Internet will be used to educate consumers. Authorization of $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2006 is provided for education programs on dietary supplements through public forums, advertisements, and the Internet. The Secretary will establish a system for reporting serious adverse experiences related to dietary supplements. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
